headline: Democrats ratchet-up anti-Trump rhetoric ahead of Robert Mueller's testimony
subHeadline: President Trump's critics pin impeachment hopes on former special counsel Robert Mueller's testimony; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Dagen McDowell, Juan Williams, Kennedy, and Tyrus. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." The Democrats are desperately trying to revive the Russian collusion talking points ahead of this week's hearing with former special counsel Robert Mueller. Now, even though Mueller didn't find any collusion and the DOJ ruled there was no obstruction, Democrats refuse to accept reality and move on. For example, House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler saying the report could provide evidence for impeachment.

utterances.speaker: REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY)
utterances.sentences: The report presents a very substantial evidence that the president is guilty of high crimes and misdemeanors, and we have to present or let Mueller present those facts to the American people and then see where we go from there, because the administration must be held accountable and no president can be above the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: House intel chief Adam Schiff is going even further by claiming Trump could end up in jail.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: He is a -- essentially unindicted co-conspirator. He's been identified as an individual one as the person who directed Michael Cohen to commit this fraudulent campaign scheme. For my point of view, if the evidence supports that he should be indicted.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Texas congressman, Al Green, not giving up on his impeachment fantasy.

utterances.speaker: REP. AL GREEN (D-TX)
utterances.sentences: This president will be impeached, I am convinced of it. I believe my colleagues are moving in this direction, and I trust that it will happen sooner rather than later.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: President Trump responding by dismissing the hearing as an attempt to resurrect the witch hunt.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to be watching -- probably, maybe I'll see a little bit of it. I'm not going to be watching Mueller because you can't take all those bites out of the apple. We had no collusion, no obstruction. We have no nothing. We had a total no collusion finding. The Democrats were devastated by it. All they care about is a pony investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's definitely not going to be watching the Mueller hearing, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: The thing I've enjoyed most about this presidency is the MSP 3,000 aspect where he really does live tweet along with almost everything. And I really hope he does. He shouldn't hold back. Like, this is the time and the place for his impulsivity when he's digesting things in real time. But, you know, you were saying that the Democrats are dusting off the Russian collusion talking points. They better skip ahead to 2020 because the Chinese are looking at the Russians going, amateurs.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: You know, we've been infiltrated software. We've done so much more than that. Huawei.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, do you think that -- Huawei is the company that you're referring to that does software and networking. Juan, do you think the Democrats are living in the past right now and it's time to move forward?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I don't understand this. I really am puzzled --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That does not surprise me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, because the president is out there saying the Democrats and Mueller can't have a second bite at the apple. This is going to be bad for the Democrats. He's apparently alarmed as if he's got something to hide. I thought no obstruction, no collusion --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Something to hide, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He should be asking Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's like a 400 page report.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He should be asking Mueller to stand up and say exactly what's in the report. Instead, he's running like -- you know, like -- you know, something's wrong. Nobody pay attention. Nobody home. Nobody here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He looked like he was sitting to me. Tyrus, this is like Mueller hearing weak.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Listen, this whole process I say I would go with Mueller's report. You know, like, typically when an investigation happens I like to get to the end before I pass judgment. I'm weird that way. And I don't think -- and Mueller was very straightforward guy. I don't see him saying anything different except maybe turn to page 35, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: You know, for every question they ask --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he's going to be like 27. I think I answered that. I don't think this is gonna be a very exciting day for either side. I think we just -- at the end of this we'll learn that the Democrats thinks that he committed high crime, and the Republicans don't believe he did, and that's exactly will be at the end of the day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he's not a very exciting person, but I think the most exciting part is going to be the Republicans on the committee asking some really tough questions that Mueller has not answered.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, Jesse. When did you determine there was no conspiracy? At what point after the last FISA warrant renewal in June of 2017, you didn't renew it in the fall. Did you find out then and why didn't you let the American people know there was no conspiracy before the midterm elections? Why didn't you investigate the predicate of the original counterintelligence investigation? What launched this? Can you tell us that? It's going to be a field day for Republicans. For the Democrats, Jerry Nadler is just trying to ruffle up some interest in impeachment because the numbers have been falling, 21 percent according to the latest Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll, the share of Americans in favor of impeachment hearings, 21 percent down six points, even down nine points to 39 percent for the Democrats.   So he's trying to have a dog and pony show. The only problem is no dogs or ponies are going to be there. Dogs and ponies are awesome. Instead, it's an old rooster, Bob Mueller, and a bunch of Weeble Wobble.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. You know who's been standing on one leg in this circus, Dagen? Bill Barr. Bill Barr absolutely spun America and he said no obstruction, no collusion. Well, if that's the case. And, by the way, Bill Barr said, go ahead, Mr. Mueller, testify.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Then -- Juan, I think that's the most important thing then because if you have some sort of a disconnect between what the attorney general said when he summarized the report and the author of the report, Special Counsel Robert Mueller, then, you know, Republicans and Democrats should really try to reconcile --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fine --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: But -- and I think that's very fair. And I think we should get to the bottom of that because we deserve the truth. The thing that's problematic for Democrats is what Dagen's talking about, I don't think they're going to find anything new. I don't think they're going to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- jostle Robert Mueller's brain. He's gonna go, oh, my gosh, you guys, I totally forgot. There was this one thing and I meant to charge him, and he has to be removed from office now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And then Hillary flies in --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. So here's -- to that point here's the real question I think Democrats could ask, and it's something that we all want to know, Republicans and Democrats. Is the only reason that you chose not to indict this president because of Justice Department policy against indicting a sitting president? And, if that's the case, why didn't you talk to the president? Why didn't you talk to Don Jr.? Why did you make these conclusions?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But Don Jr. didn't speak to the Mueller team? Yes, he did, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don Jr. spoke to the team, OK? And the president gave written answers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Not to Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When you -- yes, he did. When you are out in the streets, when you're out in the bars, when you're out with your people --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: When you're out picnicking --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When you're out picnicking at the Ferris wheel, when you're out - -

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: Under cherry trees --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- in society.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: -- enjoying life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Has anyone came up to you and say anything at all? Mueller, could you believe that?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: No, because the American people just like myself, and every day Joe, he's a little taller than everybody else, we've moved on from this. And here's the thing, Mueller is not going to -- and that was the point of the whole report. He's not going to make new law and he's not going to give personal opinions. So, I think people wanted him to say, hey, what would you do in that situation? He said based on the laws in front of me, this is my report, and it's the same thing.  Now, if our rules are different as far as what a sitting president can and cannot do, then we need to look at that. But he's not going to create -- that's what the Supreme Court is for, and that's not what Mueller is gonna do.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: If you read the Mueller report, and I read the Mueller report, volume 1, volume 2 -- volume 2 at the end of the day, no investigation was obstructed. Not the FBI counterintelligence investigation, not the Mueller investigation, 500 search warrants, no witnesses interfered, they can interview anybody that they wanted to, even people in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, and to that point the big entree, remember, was collusion. And they didn't find any conspiracy to collude with the Russians to interfere in the election. And I think the rest of the country has moved on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a second, they did find many instances -- in fact, more than a hundred of instances of context --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Context, not illegal, Juan. Not a crime.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Here's the point, they didn't find a conspiracy -- they didn't find anything written and to say, OK, this is so 100 percent locked in. We don't -- we know --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We know the Russians trying to influence this campaign. And that the Russians, in fact, wanted Donald Trump to win, but we can't lock it and that's all. To say there's no evidence --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what I would have ask, you know, if I'm up there from the congressman which -- I never -- no, never. I would say, you know, if you're supposed to be looking into Russian interference into the election - -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- why didn't you not look into the Hillary Clinton dossier?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: But that's a fair question. If you're talking about contacts from Russians, if that is the threshold, Juan, there's a lot of Russians who had contact with the person that was being paid millions of dollars by the DNC. And if it's problematic to have Russians giving someone information in order to affect the outcome of an election, that has to be problematic as well. If we're going to be consistent and we're going to apply --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Clearly, you know what? Fusion GPS is an American company, and you can hire an American company to do whatever you want.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and they can go to the Russians and say, hey --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's different than having Vladimir Putin on the line, let me tell you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: How do you know that? How do you know they were Russian nationals and contacts --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: President Obama, what did he say to him? Cut it out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Next on THE FIVE, what the heck is Beto doing? The struggling Democrat bizarre campaign and it's drawing widespread mockery.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: The 2020 circus keeps rolling on. Socialist Senator Bernie Sanders campaign is being mocked after announcing it will be cutting staffers hours in order to pay them a $15 an hour minimum wage. This is after Bernie's own staffers accused him of paying, quote, poverty wages. And what in the heck is Beto doing? The struggling Democrat posting this griming photo of himself lying on the floor of an airport and challenging his campaign staff to a push-up contest.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is your chance to do push-ups with a presidential candidate?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Jesse, who's more of an embarrassment at this point? It's a jump ball.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's toxic masculinity. I really think the push-up thing is wrong. He should have done it on his knees to be more gender inclusive. I felt like some of the women on the staff felt left out, so that would be my suggestion to him. What's going on here is they're just trying to out masculine themselves. Biden started it. But if there was a real push-up contest, this is who I think would win, either Booker or Buttigieg. Buttigieg was in the military, so it's in his veins. He's got it. And then Booker just looks jacked --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: You have to remember, Cory Booker was a division one football player, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think that's true. And also -- the Bernie thing, this is like what happens when socialism runs headfirst into capitalism. Capitalism will always win. It's like in football -- remember the Oklahoma drill one guy stands up -- boom, they run right into each other. Socialism will always lose. He's a total hypocrite. He didn't even realize that this was going to happen. I can imagine the conversation with the campaign finance chairman. Bernie, you know, if we give everybody $15 minimum wage we have to reduce their hours. Bernie is just like, come again? He doesn't understand it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It doesn't compute.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: My favorite part, Juan, was -- Bernie was upset that all this was being discussed in the media. There was one comment from him, it does bother me that people are going outside of the process and going to the media. He's this close to an inflatable raft in front of his, like, campaign bus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't get this at all because it seems to me what he's saying, in fact, was the -- just debated in Congress. In fact, the House passed this $15 wage. Lots of people think that this is not anything radical. The problem is it's a burden on a small business when you don't have a larger structure in place. For example, paying for health care, how are you gonna bump up to pay people -- really, what is a minimum wage that's a living wage, 15 bucks an hour, it's not radical. So, to me, the real problem here is that Bernie is at a moment of transition in American life. But we haven't put in place the $15 minimum wage. He wants to do it. And his staff is saying, we demand it because you're out there calling for it. So I don't think it's hypocrisy. I think he's in a squeeze.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's in a squeeze because he had to reduce their hours.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, that's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So that's the same thing that happens with private sector.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In other words, if the Congress, and as we, as the American people say, hey, the larger structure has to be changed to help small businesses like a small campaign, then he'd be able to do it. But right now, how does he pay for the health care, how does he pay for the benefits?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, sounds like a business owner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, that's right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yeah, like Amazon, $15 minimum wage. Costco, $15 minimum wage. We can go through all the private companies that pay that amount.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They're big businesses.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Well, you know what? He's got to play ball, and he basically just proves that socialism doesn't work. But I want to get back to Beto, help him.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: I can't because this is the problem when you force things. This is why Williamson is doing so great because she's -- the people are getting behind her. They're like, wow, she's -- yeah, she's weird but she's genuine, and that's what the American people like. The push-up contest one for that poor brother over there in the orange shirt, if you guys --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's struggling.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: He hates his job right now. Raise the wage to 17. If they offer him 20 bucks an hour, he's literally, like, I'm so -- look at him --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like, you posted this?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: They're doing like five and six, he's on four, poor kids. Not fair. He didn't sign up for that. But, you know, to go back to that, this is what a lot of small businesses are doing. Like, for example, I live in Louisiana, a lot of business tried to be proactive. We're going to bump people up to $15 an hour. What they end up doing is they fire half the staff so they can make the coverage, because not only in paying more, then they have to increase their type of insurance. So they have to pay more for insurance for an employee that makes $15 an hour is they higher rate of insurance.  So what ends up happening is they have to cut half the staff, and the staff has to make up for that work in a short amount of time, which puts stress on employees. Like, you get $15 an hour but you have to work a lot harder. So there's a lot of problems with just saying, we need to move it all up to this. I think it really has to depends on jobs. That's why you continue to improve to get better jobs. Like, I didn't stay at Arby's, you know what I'm saying, for a reasons.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: I didn't stay there for a reason.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And these people won't stay like the Sanders campaign.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: You know what I'm saying? They can't.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: But you have to realize Bernie Sanders campaign is in the 1 percent. You know, he's a top-tier presidential candidate. He has millions and millions of donors. And even still, he can't support his most basic ideas, and he's having to do what small businesses have to do. Of course, Amazon and Costco can afford to pay their workers $15 an hour. Mom-and-pop businesses they can't afford it. And if the government forces them to do that, they're going to force them out of business. And Bernie Sanders isn't going to have the kind of help that he needs to run the campaign that is going to get him the nomination, which is a lot of people all over the country, particularly in these critical states, knocking on doors, because those are the people who have their hours cut. And they're going to go from 60 hours a week to 42 hours a week, and that's not going to be enough, and that is the reality. And that's why they don't have minimum wage laws in places like Sweden and Denmark.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What we know is that, in fact, as you guys have said, some people get hurt by this. But more people are help in terms of higher wages that allow them to support their families.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Oh, actually, the CBO just did an analysis, a nonpartisan analysis, that showed 3.7 million people will lose their jobs when a $15 an hour --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- benefit from the higher pay. As I've said last week --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: They won't benefit from a higher pay because they're never going to get a higher pay because it's always going to stay at $15 an hour.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's $15 right now --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- places like California, they will be stuck at $15 an hour. You will have more homelessness

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fifteen is a bump from where we are now. As I've said last week --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: It's not a bump if you're out of a job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- illegal aliens to work on his property, that's the hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, then he fired them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Way to digress there, Juan. I wanted to end on Beto doing his push-ups. You can't run for president if you don't know who you are, can't you? I think that's the message. Growing concerns in Costa Rica, meantime, after a tainted alcohol kills 19 people. The shocking details next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A deadly crisis in Costa Rica raising major new concerns about vacation travel. Officials there now have confirms 19 deaths from alcohol tainted with methanol. The government's health ministry saying 14 men, 5 women, ranging in age from 32 to 72, have died over the past two months, and so far authorities have seized 30,000 bottlers alcohol suspected of being tainted. As you remember, investigators are looking at bootleg liquor as the possible cause of death of several Americans in the Dominican Republic. Dagen, what's your reaction? I mean, it's so unbelievable that someone would poison alcohol and give it to you. I mean, it's a little bit like, you know, we hear about like cocaine and heroin sometimes being poisoned with things, but this is supposedly regulated content, alcohol?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: It's probably toxic moonshine which kills people around the world every year, even earlier this year. If you go back and just Googled toxic moonshine, there were 154 people killed in India, a couple hundred more hospitalize after drinking this. And based on my background growing up in the rural south, I made some phone calls about how this happens. It's not somebody putting methanol into the alcohol. What happens is when you distill moonshine and the very first -- the very first vapors to boil off during distillation, this contains like your most volatile alcohol including methanol. It's called the 4 shot. And so in southern lingo, you say throw away the first cut because that's where the very dangerous methanol is. It comes from pectin when you make corn liquor. Corn has pectin in it. That's why you get the toxicity in this alcohol. It's basically somebody who doesn't know how to make moonshine making it, and somehow --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Well, it's also someone who doesn't want to throw anything away. And they want to use as much as possible, so they have higher margin and they make money on whatever illegal alcohol they're selling. But they have no way of detecting --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is really new to me. I didn't know --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: And nobody is following this. I mean --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: I'm learning so much right now.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Two-thirds of a shot of methanol to cause permanent blindness.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No, that's the old joke about drinking moonshine that it makes you blind. I don't mean to interrupt, but I actually --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: No, please do because no one is following this. I mean --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: If you called anybody who has ever made real moonshine and still in the woods, the first thing they'll say to you is throw away the first cut.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. So, Jesse, this is so interesting. It comes as a revelation because I thought someone was poisoning the alcohol. They're saying, no. They're just bad distillers. But, Jesse, again, the whole argument from conservatives typically is less government, less regulation, this would be an argument for -- thank God, the government is telling people how to do this and checking to make sure they don't poison them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Way to spin it against Republicans, Juan. Well done. And there's no such thing as no regulation. You've got to have something there to check the bottles. And that's why I brought a little cheat sheet if you guys are ever in a bar.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: We have a cheat sheet. It's right there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: These cheat sheets got nothing on what she's doing. Go ahead, try.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That sounds kind of obvious, but a lot of people don't do that. Number two, there should be an authentic hologram right beneath the bottle cap, and that means it's legit. So when you pour it upside down and like that when it's tapped and you see, you should not see any little particles there floating around, that means it's contaminated. The glue on most of the labels is very specific. You shouldn't be able to just pull up the label.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: With your teeth.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: I don't know about teeth. That sounds weird. I would do it with my hands --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Then maybe you're drinking some tainted alcohol.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: But to that, to your point hers is better because it was happened before the bottling process. If it's mixes bad, it's going bad in the bottle.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: No, because they can take used bottles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not competing for--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: They could take used bottles--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Moonshine knowledge. I'm trying to teach the audience how to avoid--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Come up and then pour in whatever they made and then they sell them as new bottles. They're just essentially reusing the bottles and putting other stuff in there. But it's kind of poke holes in your theory.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Someone from another island was going to the Dominican Republic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Also, glad you brought that up, because I wanted to update my suspect list. TYRUS: He has the transcripts, ladies and gentlemen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.sentences: He has the transcripts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I am now crossing off the U.S. Virgin Islands is one of the top suspects. I did some investigations. They are now - they have an alibi. OK. Let's just put it that way. Barbados and the Aruba and Puerto Rico still remain suspects at large. They have a lot of motivation for this Caribbean espionage and they will you know remain at large. WILLIAMS: Wait a second, so you think the Puerto Ricans and the Barbados--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: He is a -- essentially unindicted co-conspirator. He's been identified as an individual one as the person who directed Michael Cohen to commit this fraudulent campaign scheme. For my point of view, if the evidence supports that he should be indicted.

utterances.utterance: This president will be impeached, I am convinced of it. I believe my colleagues are moving in this direction, and I trust that it will happen sooner rather than later.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump responding by dismissing the hearing as an attempt to resurrect the witch hunt.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to be watching -- probably, maybe I'll see a little bit of it. I'm not going to be watching Mueller because you can't take all those bites out of the apple. We had no collusion, no obstruction. We have no nothing. We had a total no collusion finding. The Democrats were devastated by it. All they care about is a pony investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's definitely not going to be watching the Mueller hearing, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: The thing I've enjoyed most about this presidency is the MSP 3,000 aspect where he really does live tweet along with almost everything. And I really hope he does. He shouldn't hold back. Like, this is the time and the place for his impulsivity when he's digesting things in real time. But, you know, you were saying that the Democrats are dusting off the Russian collusion talking points. They better skip ahead to 2020 because the Chinese are looking at the Russians going, amateurs.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: You know, we've been infiltrated software. We've done so much more than that. Huawei.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, do you think that -- Huawei is the company that you're referring to that does software and networking. Juan, do you think the Democrats are living in the past right now and it's time to move forward?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't understand this. I really am puzzled --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That does not surprise me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, because the president is out there saying the Democrats and Mueller can't have a second bite at the apple. This is going to be bad for the Democrats. He's apparently alarmed as if he's got something to hide. I thought no obstruction, no collusion --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Something to hide, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He should be asking Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like a 400 page report.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He should be asking Mueller to stand up and say exactly what's in the report. Instead, he's running like -- you know, like -- you know, something's wrong. Nobody pay attention. Nobody home. Nobody here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He looked like he was sitting to me. Tyrus, this is like Mueller hearing weak.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Listen, this whole process I say I would go with Mueller's report. You know, like, typically when an investigation happens I like to get to the end before I pass judgment. I'm weird that way. And I don't think -- and Mueller was very straightforward guy. I don't see him saying anything different except maybe turn to page 35, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You know, for every question they ask --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he's going to be like 27. I think I answered that. I don't think this is gonna be a very exciting day for either side. I think we just -- at the end of this we'll learn that the Democrats thinks that he committed high crime, and the Republicans don't believe he did, and that's exactly will be at the end of the day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he's not a very exciting person, but I think the most exciting part is going to be the Republicans on the committee asking some really tough questions that Mueller has not answered.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Absolutely, Jesse. When did you determine there was no conspiracy? At what point after the last FISA warrant renewal in June of 2017, you didn't renew it in the fall. Did you find out then and why didn't you let the American people know there was no conspiracy before the midterm elections? Why didn't you investigate the predicate of the original counterintelligence investigation? What launched this? Can you tell us that? It's going to be a field day for Republicans. For the Democrats, Jerry Nadler is just trying to ruffle up some interest in impeachment because the numbers have been falling, 21 percent according to the latest Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll, the share of Americans in favor of impeachment hearings, 21 percent down six points, even down nine points to 39 percent for the Democrats. So he's trying to have a dog and pony show. The only problem is no dogs or ponies are going to be there. Dogs and ponies are awesome. Instead, it's an old rooster, Bob Mueller, and a bunch of Weeble Wobble.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. You know who's been standing on one leg in this circus, Dagen? Bill Barr. Bill Barr absolutely spun America and he said no obstruction, no collusion. Well, if that's the case. And, by the way, Bill Barr said, go ahead, Mr. Mueller, testify.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Then -- Juan, I think that's the most important thing then because if you have some sort of a disconnect between what the attorney general said when he summarized the report and the author of the report, Special Counsel Robert Mueller, then, you know, Republicans and Democrats should really try to reconcile --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fine --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: But -- and I think that's very fair. And I think we should get to the bottom of that because we deserve the truth. The thing that's problematic for Democrats is what Dagen's talking about, I don't think they're going to find anything new. I don't think they're going to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- jostle Robert Mueller's brain. He's gonna go, oh, my gosh, you guys, I totally forgot. There was this one thing and I meant to charge him, and he has to be removed from office now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And then Hillary flies in --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So here's -- to that point here's the real question I think Democrats could ask, and it's something that we all want to know, Republicans and Democrats. Is the only reason that you chose not to indict this president because of Justice Department policy against indicting a sitting president? And, if that's the case, why didn't you talk to the president? Why didn't you talk to Don Jr.? Why did you make these conclusions?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But Don Jr. didn't speak to the Mueller team? Yes, he did, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don Jr. spoke to the team, OK? And the president gave written answers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not to Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When you -- yes, he did. When you are out in the streets, when you're out in the bars, when you're out with your people --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: When you're out picnicking --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When you're out picnicking at the Ferris wheel, when you're out - -

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Under cherry trees --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- in society.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: -- enjoying life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Has anyone came up to you and say anything at all? Mueller, could you believe that?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: No, because the American people just like myself, and every day Joe, he's a little taller than everybody else, we've moved on from this. And here's the thing, Mueller is not going to -- and that was the point of the whole report. He's not going to make new law and he's not going to give personal opinions. So, I think people wanted him to say, hey, what would you do in that situation? He said based on the laws in front of me, this is my report, and it's the same thing. Now, if our rules are different as far as what a sitting president can and cannot do, then we need to look at that. But he's not going to create -- that's what the Supreme Court is for, and that's not what Mueller is gonna do.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: If you read the Mueller report, and I read the Mueller report, volume 1, volume 2 -- volume 2 at the end of the day, no investigation was obstructed. Not the FBI counterintelligence investigation, not the Mueller investigation, 500 search warrants, no witnesses interfered, they can interview anybody that they wanted to, even people in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and to that point the big entree, remember, was collusion. And they didn't find any conspiracy to collude with the Russians to interfere in the election. And I think the rest of the country has moved on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, they did find many instances -- in fact, more than a hundred of instances of context --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Context, not illegal, Juan. Not a crime.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's the point, they didn't find a conspiracy -- they didn't find anything written and to say, OK, this is so 100 percent locked in. We don't -- we know --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We know the Russians trying to influence this campaign. And that the Russians, in fact, wanted Donald Trump to win, but we can't lock it and that's all. To say there's no evidence --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what I would have ask, you know, if I'm up there from the congressman which -- I never -- no, never. I would say, you know, if you're supposed to be looking into Russian interference into the election - -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- why didn't you not look into the Hillary Clinton dossier?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: But that's a fair question. If you're talking about contacts from Russians, if that is the threshold, Juan, there's a lot of Russians who had contact with the person that was being paid millions of dollars by the DNC. And if it's problematic to have Russians giving someone information in order to affect the outcome of an election, that has to be problematic as well. If we're going to be consistent and we're going to apply --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Clearly, you know what? Fusion GPS is an American company, and you can hire an American company to do whatever you want.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, and they can go to the Russians and say, hey --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's different than having Vladimir Putin on the line, let me tell you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: How do you know that? How do you know they were Russian nationals and contacts --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: President Obama, what did he say to him? Cut it out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Next on THE FIVE, what the heck is Beto doing? The struggling Democrat bizarre campaign and it's drawing widespread mockery.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: The 2020 circus keeps rolling on. Socialist Senator Bernie Sanders campaign is being mocked after announcing it will be cutting staffers hours in order to pay them a $15 an hour minimum wage. This is after Bernie's own staffers accused him of paying, quote, poverty wages. And what in the heck is Beto doing? The struggling Democrat posting this griming photo of himself lying on the floor of an airport and challenging his campaign staff to a push-up contest.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is your chance to do push-ups with a presidential candidate?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Jesse, who's more of an embarrassment at this point? It's a jump ball.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's toxic masculinity. I really think the push-up thing is wrong. He should have done it on his knees to be more gender inclusive. I felt like some of the women on the staff felt left out, so that would be my suggestion to him. What's going on here is they're just trying to out masculine themselves. Biden started it. But if there was a real push-up contest, this is who I think would win, either Booker or Buttigieg. Buttigieg was in the military, so it's in his veins. He's got it. And then Booker just looks jacked --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: You have to remember, Cory Booker was a division one football player, too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think that's true. And also -- the Bernie thing, this is like what happens when socialism runs headfirst into capitalism. Capitalism will always win. It's like in football -- remember the Oklahoma drill one guy stands up -- boom, they run right into each other. Socialism will always lose. He's a total hypocrite. He didn't even realize that this was going to happen. I can imagine the conversation with the campaign finance chairman. Bernie, you know, if we give everybody $15 minimum wage we have to reduce their hours. Bernie is just like, come again? He doesn't understand it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It doesn't compute.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: My favorite part, Juan, was -- Bernie was upset that all this was being discussed in the media. There was one comment from him, it does bother me that people are going outside of the process and going to the media. He's this close to an inflatable raft in front of his, like, campaign bus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't get this at all because it seems to me what he's saying, in fact, was the -- just debated in Congress. In fact, the House passed this $15 wage. Lots of people think that this is not anything radical. The problem is it's a burden on a small business when you don't have a larger structure in place. For example, paying for health care, how are you gonna bump up to pay people -- really, what is a minimum wage that's a living wage, 15 bucks an hour, it's not radical. So, to me, the real problem here is that Bernie is at a moment of transition in American life. But we haven't put in place the $15 minimum wage. He wants to do it. And his staff is saying, we demand it because you're out there calling for it. So I don't think it's hypocrisy. I think he's in a squeeze.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's in a squeeze because he had to reduce their hours.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So that's the same thing that happens with private sector.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In other words, if the Congress, and as we, as the American people say, hey, the larger structure has to be changed to help small businesses like a small campaign, then he'd be able to do it. But right now, how does he pay for the health care, how does he pay for the benefits?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, sounds like a business owner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yeah, like Amazon, $15 minimum wage. Costco, $15 minimum wage. We can go through all the private companies that pay that amount.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They're big businesses.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what? He's got to play ball, and he basically just proves that socialism doesn't work. But I want to get back to Beto, help him.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I can't because this is the problem when you force things. This is why Williamson is doing so great because she's -- the people are getting behind her. They're like, wow, she's -- yeah, she's weird but she's genuine, and that's what the American people like. The push-up contest one for that poor brother over there in the orange shirt, if you guys --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's struggling.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: He hates his job right now. Raise the wage to 17. If they offer him 20 bucks an hour, he's literally, like, I'm so -- look at him --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like, you posted this?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: They're doing like five and six, he's on four, poor kids. Not fair. He didn't sign up for that. But, you know, to go back to that, this is what a lot of small businesses are doing. Like, for example, I live in Louisiana, a lot of business tried to be proactive. We're going to bump people up to $15 an hour. What they end up doing is they fire half the staff so they can make the coverage, because not only in paying more, then they have to increase their type of insurance. So they have to pay more for insurance for an employee that makes $15 an hour is they higher rate of insurance. So what ends up happening is they have to cut half the staff, and the staff has to make up for that work in a short amount of time, which puts stress on employees. Like, you get $15 an hour but you have to work a lot harder. So there's a lot of problems with just saying, we need to move it all up to this. I think it really has to depends on jobs. That's why you continue to improve to get better jobs. Like, I didn't stay at Arby's, you know what I'm saying, for a reasons.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I didn't stay there for a reason.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And these people won't stay like the Sanders campaign.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You know what I'm saying? They can't.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: But you have to realize Bernie Sanders campaign is in the 1 percent. You know, he's a top-tier presidential candidate. He has millions and millions of donors. And even still, he can't support his most basic ideas, and he's having to do what small businesses have to do. Of course, Amazon and Costco can afford to pay their workers $15 an hour. Mom-and-pop businesses they can't afford it. And if the government forces them to do that, they're going to force them out of business. And Bernie Sanders isn't going to have the kind of help that he needs to run the campaign that is going to get him the nomination, which is a lot of people all over the country, particularly in these critical states, knocking on doors, because those are the people who have their hours cut. And they're going to go from 60 hours a week to 42 hours a week, and that's not going to be enough, and that is the reality. And that's why they don't have minimum wage laws in places like Sweden and Denmark.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What we know is that, in fact, as you guys have said, some people get hurt by this. But more people are help in terms of higher wages that allow them to support their families.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Oh, actually, the CBO just did an analysis, a nonpartisan analysis, that showed 3.7 million people will lose their jobs when a $15 an hour --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- benefit from the higher pay. As I've said last week --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: They won't benefit from a higher pay because they're never going to get a higher pay because it's always going to stay at $15 an hour.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's $15 right now --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- places like California, they will be stuck at $15 an hour. You will have more homelessness

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fifteen is a bump from where we are now. As I've said last week --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's not a bump if you're out of a job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- illegal aliens to work on his property, that's the hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, then he fired them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Way to digress there, Juan. I wanted to end on Beto doing his push-ups. You can't run for president if you don't know who you are, can't you? I think that's the message. Growing concerns in Costa Rica, meantime, after a tainted alcohol kills 19 people. The shocking details next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A deadly crisis in Costa Rica raising major new concerns about vacation travel. Officials there now have confirms 19 deaths from alcohol tainted with methanol. The government's health ministry saying 14 men, 5 women, ranging in age from 32 to 72, have died over the past two months, and so far authorities have seized 30,000 bottlers alcohol suspected of being tainted. As you remember, investigators are looking at bootleg liquor as the possible cause of death of several Americans in the Dominican Republic. Dagen, what's your reaction? I mean, it's so unbelievable that someone would poison alcohol and give it to you. I mean, it's a little bit like, you know, we hear about like cocaine and heroin sometimes being poisoned with things, but this is supposedly regulated content, alcohol?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's probably toxic moonshine which kills people around the world every year, even earlier this year. If you go back and just Googled toxic moonshine, there were 154 people killed in India, a couple hundred more hospitalize after drinking this. And based on my background growing up in the rural south, I made some phone calls about how this happens. It's not somebody putting methanol into the alcohol. What happens is when you distill moonshine and the very first -- the very first vapors to boil off during distillation, this contains like your most volatile alcohol including methanol. It's called the 4 shot. And so in southern lingo, you say throw away the first cut because that's where the very dangerous methanol is. It comes from pectin when you make corn liquor. Corn has pectin in it. That's why you get the toxicity in this alcohol. It's basically somebody who doesn't know how to make moonshine making it, and somehow --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Well, it's also someone who doesn't want to throw anything away. And they want to use as much as possible, so they have higher margin and they make money on whatever illegal alcohol they're selling. But they have no way of detecting --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is really new to me. I didn't know --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: And nobody is following this. I mean --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I'm learning so much right now.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Two-thirds of a shot of methanol to cause permanent blindness.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No, that's the old joke about drinking moonshine that it makes you blind. I don't mean to interrupt, but I actually --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: No, please do because no one is following this. I mean --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: If you called anybody who has ever made real moonshine and still in the woods, the first thing they'll say to you is throw away the first cut.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Jesse, this is so interesting. It comes as a revelation because I thought someone was poisoning the alcohol. They're saying, no. They're just bad distillers. But, Jesse, again, the whole argument from conservatives typically is less government, less regulation, this would be an argument for -- thank God, the government is telling people how to do this and checking to make sure they don't poison them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Way to spin it against Republicans, Juan. Well done. And there's no such thing as no regulation. You've got to have something there to check the bottles. And that's why I brought a little cheat sheet if you guys are ever in a bar.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: We have a cheat sheet. It's right there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: These cheat sheets got nothing on what she's doing. Go ahead, try.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That sounds kind of obvious, but a lot of people don't do that. Number two, there should be an authentic hologram right beneath the bottle cap, and that means it's legit. So when you pour it upside down and like that when it's tapped and you see, you should not see any little particles there floating around, that means it's contaminated. The glue on most of the labels is very specific. You shouldn't be able to just pull up the label.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With your teeth.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I don't know about teeth. That sounds weird. I would do it with my hands --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Then maybe you're drinking some tainted alcohol.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: But to that, to your point hers is better because it was happened before the bottling process. If it's mixes bad, it's going bad in the bottle.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No, because they can take used bottles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not competing for--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: They could take used bottles--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Moonshine knowledge. I'm trying to teach the audience how to avoid--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Come up and then pour in whatever they made and then they sell them as new bottles. They're just essentially reusing the bottles and putting other stuff in there. But it's kind of poke holes in your theory.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Someone from another island was going to the Dominican Republic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, glad you brought that up, because I wanted to update my suspect list. TYRUS: He has the transcripts, ladies and gentlemen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: He has the transcripts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I am now crossing off the U.S. Virgin Islands is one of the top suspects. I did some investigations. They are now - they have an alibi. OK. Let's just put it that way. Barbados and the Aruba and Puerto Rico still remain suspects at large. They have a lot of motivation for this Caribbean espionage and they will you know remain at large. WILLIAMS: Wait a second, so you think the Puerto Ricans and the Barbados--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying there is a lot of competition for tourism dollars Juan in the Caribbean. And they're not going to let them off the hook yet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They're shipping bad alcohol to the foreigners--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Traders, it's not necessarily happening there. It's an inside job.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: OK. So, we know that 14 Americans have died in the Dominican Republic in the last two years. We know that--

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Not going there.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: 19 people have died in Costa Rica. They're not necessarily Americans. I want to know how many non-Americans died in the Dominican from the same thing. And that's a problem--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think the Americans are being targeted.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think it's the Americans, I think there are so many people--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: There are literally--

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Poisoned that they're not releasing those statistics and causes of death. MCDOWELL: There are people around the world being poisoned by bad moonshine again because they don't have hillbillies. WILLIAMS: By the way, there is a new brand of alcohol called Angels Cut. And when I heard what you just said, you said you should throw that away--

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: That's kind of sad. Cut Ange, I'm not messing with that. WILLIAMS: You're not messing with that. And by the way, I like the idea that government regulates, and I can trust that I'd pick up a bottle that it's not been--

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL

But the difference between the Apollo program and now, Elizabeth Warren is saying, we all came together, and we got guys on the moon and that was pretty historic, 50 years ago. A phenomenal feat that JFK called out in 1961, by the end of this decade we're going to have a man on the moon. And that happened. But you have to bring people together in order to do that. utterances.utterance: Wait a second, what are you saying, how is it pushing if there is a real problem.
